06. Accordin to Ilya Petrikeich / От Ильи Петрикеича

by Sasha Sokolov

Translated by Alexander Boguslawski

With what does the station’s waitin room wallop us tactlessly on the nose? Don’t consider it a complaint, but in its mass the public stinks like a wet and homeless dog. Our armpits started hurtin from ice-covered roads, migraine blurred our eyes. Due to fatigue, we visit a railroad drinkin hole—we’re takin medicine. I asked Alfeyev, where are you goin now? He considers: Mother Russia is huge, playful, and she barks like a she-wolf in the fog, and we, like flies, hop on the top of her, and she bites us out one after another as we hop, and it’s impossible to figure out where it would be best to jump off, halloo, ever. True, Yasha, halloo, in our radiant country we’re all like a bone stuck in its throat, we’re all debtors, we’re all at fault. And my real mother, he said, perhaps died, and I’m lackin a permanent father ’cuz of alcoholism; I only heard he was called Ilya. Yasha, my dear, perhaps I am he, perhaps there happened some kids in a hurry, after all, life is also huge. I allow that, answered Ilyich, but if it’s so, why did you completely abandon my mother, did not help the woman get her son on his feet, did not give him a vocational education; after all that, you are a rat for me and not dad. And he got offended. Yakov Ilyich, I cheered him up, stop bein cross, perhaps I am no father of yours at all, calm down a bit, do not get too excited, do not. Excuse me, he says, I blew my top, perhaps you ain’t my father. But it’s possible, I am hangin on contrariwise, it’s possible that precisely your father, who knows? Therefore, let me be not simply a father but a possible-father, I will be a possible-father to you. Be so, uttered Alfeyev, why should I care? In that case, I take the lad on his word, you could lend me, such an inexact dad of yours, money for a ticket without a reserved seat: Gimme an advance, I need to get to the Tower Junction, to a certain Joy Whatshername. Don’t refuse the request, help the old man, ain’t you his flesh and blood, perhaps? Yakov Ilyich sheds crocodile tears at the train station: Daddy, Ilyusha, prodigerant, you’re gettin ready to see our mother, even if she’s no longer among the livin, perhaps. I got confused: Why her exactly? ’Cuz, he says, she also worked at the station. And what about her last name, first name, and initials in general? Well, I don’t give a darn about them initials, he screamed, whatever they might be, why are you goin on like a stranger of little faith? And he bought me a ticket to the Tower Junction. For farewell we hugged, smooched—so take care, we won’t see each other, the huge she-wolf is spread far and wide. And he gave me substantial notes; I received them, crumpled them, stashed them in my valenok—and adieu. I am ridin on the train, broodin: You’re a miserable wretch, Yakov Ilyich, an orphan, your father is a swindler, a rapscallion, he did not help your mother at all, and the latter was of easy virtue, and there is, very likely, hardly a spot to put a proof of purity on her, even if she ain’t the one Whatshername. Those from the Tower Junction, they are all nothin but fine broads—whether this one or the twelfth, but, anyway, I am goin to this one, ’cuz the twelfth I don’t freakin need. That’s what I was thinkin about my relatives, languishin in the pitiful car with no reserved seats, amidst all the others afflicted, like me, by poverty. And it was rockin on switches. Roll up your eyelids like a pant leg, bare your stump, too—so it is more spectacular—and scoot to the car with reserved seats: Your instrument’s with you. Immediately start a melody and announce over the knockin and dancin of the wheels that you know no peace, and don’t have any joy either—you suffered a misfortune. And after that esplain what happened. But don’t be concerned about nourishment, don’t beg for Christ’s sake, don’t moan and don’t groan, and, speakin heart-to-heart, carry high the lofty name of the folk invalidual, since even the most horriblest of us is better than fowls of the air. And those who get emotional—they will loosen their purse strings on their own. So you begin the concert. I will stretch a spool of thread to the green lea’s end, or I’ll pound a telegram to my dearest friend. Here it is, the much-beloved Russian song; it flows and splashes all over the premises—and the journey is long. And from where, You’ll inquire, do you, Ilya, have an acordeon, have you sold some manure, Your Lameness? No, I haven’t sold any manure and such an extraordinary dough, to buy the music, I haven’t ever held in my hands out of principle. But our real world does not befall us without such generous souls as our orderly. They brought to Uncle Vanya at the theater an artist from the outskirts, a victim of dangerous razors, in a tilted cap and with a gold tooth. And he was, apparently, such a passionate musician that even his kirza boots were like an acordeon. At the same time his three-row instrument was brought along with him. The male nurse credited the account on behalf of the poor, but, he used to say, the bandura appears to be of no use: Whenever I try to play, right away it becomes clear I don’t know how: either my hands are shakin or my voice breaks up. But I, I kept promisin, I know how, just let me. They handed it over. How I pulled the bellows, how I worked out a fingerin on them pimples! Now play somethin ours, the orderly implores, yank away! Once the boozin started, I whipped chastushkas at a full swing. Crematorium they were tryin, homeless vagrant they were fryin (the management’s so shrewd), they look in—and he is teasin: Close the door, my butt is freezin. Whoever was present there in the cellar broke into a crazy dance, and look, even Yakov Ilyich on his one and only makes a freak of himself. Uncle Vanya also bends his knees and I hear, as if in a heavenly swoon: I see, I see, you can, here’s the hurdy-gurdy for you from my white shoulder.

And in trains they simply could not stop praisin me. One courier even called me to his compartment: Let me pour you a drink. Ain’t You disgusted hobnobbin with me? Phew, he laughs, I used to gobble from the common bowl with worse than you. And he pours. Why are You temptin me, citizen, what if I don’t hold back? Be so kind, go ahead. And he’s completely bare, like a cantaloupe. I gulped. And he goes: At a train station there sat a soldier, a rake and dandy, brother-in-arms, just a lieutenant by rankin order, but a field marshal of female charms. I am a brainy bayan player, I made up a melody for him on the fly, in two-fourths. A certain madam entered the station, and she was serious, graceful, and neat; lieutenant quickly stood at attention and dropped his breeches straight at her feet. And a chorus. And I, too, said my travelin companion, was a lieutenant, like in the song. I wore cartridge belts and a mustache, but due to my manners and my rank, I was registered as a deputy. But not of some railroad female charms, no, in my license I was registered as a deputy inspector of all cast-iron roads. And he pours me, just imagine, Armenian delight. You must have lost Your mind, to waste three stars on a person with no passport. And he only sparkles with his buttons. And for that reason, he admits, the railroad destiny is dear to me, I got used to it, I’m ashamed to say, I love, excuse me, scrambled eggs and tearin at full speed in an express rushin on. And where do you think I am goin right now? Don’t be angry, I answered, I have no clue about Your travel plans, so far I am not buyin Your tickets. So far others are buyin tickets for Ilya. Do you think that I planned to visit for a while my brother in Kazan?—the lieutenant kept questionin. Who knows what You do, I personally would gladly go to visit my brother out of the blue, and then enjoy yourself as much as you like, eat-drink-sleep. If you get bored, you can call to a get-together the neyborly Musia or you can wander with a dragnet for a while. You wander like that, You know, up to your waist in water, and the slimy clay keeps squeezin like leeches between your toes, it even curls. I get your drift, the inspector nods; frankly, my own brother is a drunk. What can I say, deputy, a brother—a brother is there, but he doesn’t send me lately any invitations, and what’s goin on with him, I have no clue: Did he get married, is he sick, or is he clinkin with his irons somewhere? No need to guess, he answered, obviously with them. But, to be honest, lieutenant, I don’t recall that he scribbled to me particularly often; no, not often did he scribble to me, even to express it better—he never wrote to me at all. In irons you won’t do much writin, the lieutenant kept noddin, in the environs of Kandalaksha. Yes, and, You see, it’s unlikely that I would put my head on a choppin block for You to prove that this brother exists anywhere at all; I suspect that he’s not present in my inventory, regrettably—neither in Kazan and Ryazan, nor in Syzran. Well, then, he says, allow me, I will pour you for that again. And both of us took a swig. And the train speeds on with widely open orbs, cuts the young night like a sharp speed skate, shines into a distance somewhere with a pair of manul’s eyes. In the scraps of the same night dozes, quietly snoozin, snuggled like a needle in a haystack, the transit passenger after surgery, like I, and to him the train seems to have a completely unearthly destination. Woe is me, old chap, the inspector sighed, in Syzran my relatives don’t live right now, in contrast, in Millerovo, please—in Millerovo there’s a full assorti; incidently, my godsister passed away there not long ago. And he introduces himself: Yemelyan Zhizhirella. Holy crap, I declared. And immediately embraced him, fatso, and he me, a humble stick. And we drained one for Bruderschaft. So why didn’t you write to me, I reproached, you could’ve at least dropped me a postcard; and you dare to call yourself a onewomber. Don’t get mad so quickly, he esplained, I had no time to write letters in the environs of Kandalaksha, in the slammer, better tell me, why do you forget your relatives: For example, durin the wake in Millerovo I don’t recall seein you at all, hadn’t you received the news? As far as receivin is concerned, I did receive it, by hand delivery. Right away, I grab my cap, catch the droshky—and to the station. I run up to a formidable one with a saber: What’s where here? He points out. And the saber has a little wheel at the bottom, to drag it more smoothly. Miss, be so kind, a ticket with a reserved seat to Millerovo. A saber like that is stronger than a bullet, ’cuz sooner or later the lead will get flattened, but from the steel you won’t wiggle out at any price, from this here steel. At the platform— high culture: spittoons and a kiosk. Eighteen minutes. And uncertainty seized me. When I arrive—there will be no end to gossip, they’ll imagine, most likely, who knows what. They have no clue, my skinflint kinsfolk, that not everybody is necessarily a cheapskate. Ilya does not need what’s someone else’s, he doesn’t even have what’s his own, but try and esplain. You can choke on your wake, I won’t go. I am standin. Here the conductor sounds the boardin, there the wagon usher curses, and over there an old lady knocks like a moth against a window glass: Dimka, her grandson, be so kind to notice, is departin to visit his uncle in Uglich. Watch out, my urchin, don’t go walkin in the heat without mittens. You yourself, skinny worm, keep both eyes open, otherwise someone may prematurely shake off your dust. Well, old man, I address the chief, are we doin the departure? And why are You intrested?—he pulled his railroad cap on his brow. I answer that for me it doesn’t really matter, that I would like to ask about somethin else, and the departure itself doesn’t bother me from any side, that—who cares about departure, go on, depart. About what else?—he teases. Have You ever been present at trottin competitions? It’s not the right word—present, I loitered there, I used to lose big sums on wagers. So You must remember how the hippodrome was burnin and the sparks were flyin, right? How could I not remember, they kept flyin, at first there were even plans to cancel the heat. There were plans, but the deal fizzled off—and the horses started traversin. From the very start, I remember, Polykleitus, the black three-year-old from Polytechnician and Kleptomania, jumped forward, but the mare Sour Cream reached the second turn first, and Polykleitus dropped to the third, and who was ridin him at the moment—my memory broke the loop. Well, if it broke then it broke, said the railman, but we better finish now with them horses, ’cuz to interrupt the departure, bein elderly, does not become You. You’re puttin on much air, old man, why don’t You, instead of ringin the bell, quickly deal us a hand? Right then, the saber rolls in: What’s up? Well, this—the departee proposes to deal a hand. Well, delay won’t make it rusty, it’s not a little wheel, we only need to procure unmarked cards. Just wait with the cards, he’s simply tryin to interrupt the departure. Have mercy, the gard flew into a rage; this is simply espionage of some kind. Don’t chastise, it won’t happen again, You understand, Your bell brought past thoughts to my mind, one was hangin at the races before the fire—like two peas in a pod. It clinked and clanked—and started rollin irrepressibly. In those twisted years, I had with me, even though personally I don’t believe it today, a commendable suitcase of crocodile leather. By the way, why twisted? Years like years, not more twisted than the others. A suitcase of crocodile leather, I repeat, with locks, in those years like years, I, Dzyndzyrella, dare to claim, did have. I grab it—and take to my heels. And it’s lashin—hard to describe. As we know, both the train and the rain were goin—one to Millerovo, the other all day. Dear bro, Yemelyan declares, how great it is to ride at full speed together to visit you in Kazan; after all, we haven’t seen each other for so long. Wait a minute, I’m gettin anxious, and did you send me a postalgram? Why do you ask, straight from the road. So now I am runnin along the embarcadero, I catch up with the train car, but to jump in, due to the lack of conviction, I’m afraid. Polishin floors in all possible places in those years like years, I carried in my suitcase waxes, rags, rubbed felt, and brushes of pig bristle. My train usher with signal flags in cases screams his lungs out from the gangway: Let go, or You’ll suddenly plunge and make a fool of Yourself, like many others did. Linen mistress, don’t mock the passenger misfortune, go plunge Yourself. And to Yemelyan I said that, halloo—his dispatch will not catch up with me and that most likely he’s hurryin to Kazan in vain—I will not run out. While to You, Sidor Fomich, I am writin approximately what follows. One day some folk come to the ferryman, and he’s sleepin soundly like a baby. Yes, this I understand, this is a riddle, ’cuz it’s a riddle and not simply a peasant true story. Only I don’t understand to which ferryman: We have two ferrymen on the Itil. That one makes money on that side, this one—on the contrary—on this one. The first, Yeryoma nicknamed Cad; the second, in contrast, Foma, and without any nickname. He’s called respectfully by his last name, so why make a fuss, don’t you think? Doom—that’s the last name of our boatman. And let’s suppose they come exactly to him: There’s work. He woke up—what kind of work? Why are you full of yourself for no reason, they say, as if besides ferryin you had a clue about some other trade? I won’t allow anyone to lecture me, noted Foma, you better lay out the fact. And the deputy flew into a rage, stomps his feet, as if I was guilty; even I, the orphan, never met myself in Kazan, to tell the truth. Well, so where am I rushin now, the inspector shouts, tell me. Deputy, I draw a blank about your intricate itineraries, but if you have in your hands your travel document, don’t consider this disrespectful and look at it—it’s stated there. To be endlessly in trouble is Ilya Dzhynzhirela’s lot. Plunge Yourself, my train usher heard my words. I said it to him rashly—and plunged myself. What a mess, pal, I plunged, fell like a sack under the wheels, and my bare footsie got sliced off like with a sickle. I see—someone familiar with a blade flies down from the heavenly rafters to help. Six-winged serafim, gardian, swing your yatagan once, chop off the whole me from these here places: I’m hurtin a lot, clumsy me. And the chief arrived in time to scold. For You it’s nothin, he got envious, You’ve secured a sanatorium for Yourself, but people will get a reprimand on Your account. Don’t curse, after all, weather’s wet, so one slips. A thought: Apparently the expedition failed, crashed, the last rites are waitin for Ilya. And I’m in trouble again, when, smug, I advise the lieutenant to look at his ticket. You’re a boob, he cuts me off, a deputy due to his title is not obliged to buy tickets, and even when he buys sometimes, he buys a special one to any destination, and whether you look at that ticket or not, everythin’s a fog, and whether its presenter is goin here or there, nobody understands, only the ticket with the reserved seat flutters in the wind and a coupon for obtainin bedsheets rustles. Yep, you sure didn’t luck out, my countryman, but apparently not always and not everywhere deputies have advantages. It turns out that non-deputies sometimes know better where their road leads. Take me for example—to Orina, gimme her here and now, I’m holdin my course to her.

Чем вокзал ожиданий шибает бестактно в нос? Не сочтите за жалобу, псиной мокрой и беспризорной преет публика в массе своей. Разболелись от гололеда у нас подмышки, замутила взоры мигрень. Навещаем с устатку путейную тут питейную — лечимся. Ты куда теперь, Алфеева я спросил. Рассуждает: Россия-матерь огромна, игрива и лает, будто волчица во мгле, а мы ровно блохи скачем по ней, а она по очереди выкусывает нас на ходу, и куда лучше прыгнуть, не разберешь, ау, никогда. Верно, Яша, ау, все мы у нашей краи́ны светлой — как поперек горла кость, все задолжники, во всем кругом виноватые. А обычная мать, он сказал, у меня умерла, может быть, и отца постоянного я лишен в результате алкоголизма, слышал только, величали Ильей. Яша, милый, да может, я он и есть, небось случались ребятишки какие-нибудь впопыхах, жизнь же тоже огромна. Допускаю, Ильич отвечал, но зачем ты в подобном случае мать забросил с концами, сына женщине поставить на ноги не помог, образования ремесленного ему не дал, подлец ты мне после этого, а не отец. И обиделся. Яков Ильич, я утешил, да ты не серчай, я еще, может, и не отец тебе никакой, охолони чуток, шибко не кипятись, шибко-то. Извиняй, говорит, погорячился, может, и не отец. А возможно, обратно примазываюсь, возможно, что как раз и отец, неизвестно еще. И поэтому пусть я буду тебе не просто отец, а отец-может-быть, может-быть-отцом стану приходиться тебе. Приходись, Алфеев изрек, мне-то что. Если так, на слове парня ловлю, то не одолжишь ли мне, как папаше такому неточному, на билет неплацкартный: займи, мне на станцию Терем, к Отраде одной Имярековой. Просьба в денежке не отказать, выручай старика, или ты не плоть от плоти его, может быть. Яков Ильич при вокзале белугой ревет: батя, Илюша, блудущий мой, ты ж к мамане нашей нагладился, пусть она у нас и не в живых, может быть. Я смешался: зачем это непременно к ней? Потому, говорит, что на станции тоже работала. А фамилия, имя, инициалы вообще? А плевать я хотел на инициалы, вскричал, какие бы ни были, что ты как маловер неродной. И купил мне билет до Терема. Облокотились взаимно мы на прощанье, облобызались — прощай-ка, не свидимся, преогромна волчица — раскинулась. Дал купюр еще он значительных, я их принял, пожамкал, затырил в валенок — и адью. Еду и маюсь: бедолага ты, Яков Ильич, сирота, жук отец твой, пройдоха, он помощь мамашке не осуществлял ни хрена, та же — поведения облегченного, и пробы на ней ставить — вряд ли, пожалуй, где есть, даже если и не та она Имярекова. Теремские — они ведь все оторвы приличные — что та, что двенадцатая, но все-таки еду к той, потому что двенадцатая ни на́ болт сдалась. Так я мыслил о родственниках своих, в бесплацкартном заплаканном томясь вместе с прочими, одержимыми, как и я, нищетой. И мотало на стрелках. На манер как бы брючины подворачивай вежды себе, заголяй и культю — чтоб чудне́й, и задвигайся в купейный: с тобой инструмент. Заводи моментально мелодию и заявляй поверх пересудов и переплясов колес, что не ведаешь мира, нет и отрады — постигло несчастие. И далее поясни, в чем суть. Однако о пропитании не заботься, не христарадничай, не канючь и не клянчь, говоря задушевно, высокое звание народного индивида неси высоко, ведь и самый из нас страшнеющий лучше птах. А кого проймет — сам раскошелится. И начинаешь концерт. Протяну катушку ниток по зеленому лужку, отобью ли телеграмму моему милу́ дружку. Вот она, разлюбимая русская песнь, льется и плещется по всему помещению — а путь далек. А откуда, заинтересуетесь, гармония у тебя, Илия, что ли, навоз Вы продали, Ваше Калечество? Нет, не продавал я навоз, и бабок столь исключительных, чтоб музыку приобресть, в руках не держал из принципа. Но не вершится свет настоящий без таких щедрых духом, как наш санитар. Завезли к дяде Ване в театр артиста окраин, жертву опасных бритв, в кепке набок и зуб золотой. И до того музыкант, вероятно, заядлый, что сапоги у него — и те гармошкой, кирза. Заодно и трехрядка его с ним сам-друг доставлена. Заприходовал ее медбрат в пользу бедных, только, сказывал, предстает бандура вне надобности: как играть я попробую — так сразу и выясняется, что не умею: то руки дрожат, то голос срывается. А я, я сулил, я умею, лишь дайте. Вручают. Как дернул меха, как выработал перебор по пупырышкам! Сбацай наше чего-нибудь, санитар умоляет, рвани. Раз пошла таковская пьянка, запузырил я частухи на полный размах. Крематорий проверяли, беспризорника сжигали (дирекция какая-нибудь хитрая), дверь открыли — он танцует и кричит: закройте, ведь дует. Пляска бешеная их всех, кто там случился в подвале, взяла, инда Яков Ильич на одной, поглядите, уродуется. Дядя Ваня тоже коленца откалывает, и слышу, как в райском обмороке: вижу, вижу, могёшь, получай ты шарманку эту с белого моего плеча.

А в поездах меня прямо захваливали. Один разъездной даже в купе зазвал — дай налью. А не гнушаетесь якшаться со мной? Тю, смеется, еще не с такими доводилось из одного корыта хлебать. Наполняет. Что вы меня искушаете, гражданин, а ну как не вытерплю? Сделай милость, валяй. Сам весь гунявый, как канталупа. Я опрокинул. Он выдает: на станции сидел один военный, обыкновенный гуляка-франт, по чину своему он был поручик, но дамских ручек был генерал. Я — баянист головитейший, мелодию ему подобрал на ходу, в два счета. На станцию вошла весьма серьезно и грациозно одна мадам, поручик расстегнул свои шкарята и бросил прямо к ее ногам. И припев. Вот и я, будто в песне, попутчик сказал, был поручиком. Носил и газыри, и усы, но по замашкам и по ранжиру числился в попечителях. Но не то что там ручек каких-нибудь станционных, нет, числился у себя в мандате попечитель-инспектором всех чугунных путей. И наливает, вообразите, армянского. Да вы трекнулись, три звездочки на беспаспортного переводить. Только пуговицами бликует. И поэтому, признается, мила мне планида железнодорожная, прикипел, грешным делом, люблю, извини, яичницу и промчаться в быстромелькающем скором. И куда же, ты думаешь, я направляюсь теперь? Не серчайте, я отвечал, я маршрутов ваших не в курсе, билетов вам не покупаю пока, Илье билеты самому пока покупают. Думаешь, я у брата, что ли, в Казани вознамерился погостить? — поручик допытывался. Кто вас знает, я к брату бы и сам с пристрастием снегом на голову, там дури сколько влезет, ешь-пей-ночуй, Мусю соседскую, если соскучился, можно на посиделки зазвать, с бредешком побродить можно бы. Бредешь так, знаете, по пояс в воде, а глина илистая — так и лезет пиявками между пальцами, аж завивается. Не говори, инспектор поддакивает, у самого, признаться, брат — пьяница. Что говорить, попечитель, брат — брат и есть, только не шлет он в последние сроки приглашений мне никаких, и что у него там стряслось — не пойму: женился ли, болен, кандалами ли где звенит? Зря сомневаешься, отвечал, ясно, ими. Но, по правде сказать, поручик, не припомню, чтоб он и прежде особенно часто строчил; нет, не часто он мне строчил, даже лучше выразиться — совсем никогда не писал. В кандалах не попишешь, поручик кивал, в Кандалакше-то. Да, и голову на плаху я вряд ли бы вам, пожалуй, свою положил за то, что имеется где бы то ни было этот братец вообще; подозреваю, что и в заводе его у меня нет, как ни жаль, — ни в Казани с Рязанью, ни в Сызрани. А ну, говорит, разреши, я тебе за это плесну сызнова. И мы куликнули оба. А состав наяривает себе ни в едином глазу, режет ночь молодую, как острый норвежский нож, катит неблизко где-нибудь вязкой манульих глаз. В околотке той же самой ночи́ дремлет, кемарит по-тихому, прикорнул швейной иглою в омете оперированный транзитный, вроде меня, и ему поезд чудится нездешнего назначения совершенно. Ахти мне, батенька, инспектор вздохнул, в Сызрани родственники не проживают сейчас, вот в Миллерове — пожалуйста, в Миллерове — полное ассорти, крестная сестрина там недавно как раз преставилась. И представляется: Емельян Жижирэлла. Едрена палка, я выразился. И сразу обнял его, жирнягу, а он меня, худобу покорного. И высушили на брудершафт. Ну зачем же ты не писал-то мне, я укорял, хоть бы открытку бросил, одноутроб еще называется. Ты с налету не гневайся, он объяснял, недосуг в Кандалакше письма было писать, в каталажке-то, лучше скажи, отчего сам родню забываешь: я, например, на поминках в Миллерове не припомню тебя совсем, или известия не получил? Получить получил, с вручением. Сей же час хватаю картуз, пролетку — и на вокзал. Подлетаю к солидному с саблей: где тут чего? Показывает. А у сабли внизу колесико, чтобы плавней волочить. Барышня, благоволите купейный до Миллерова. Сабля подобная пули сильней, ибо свинец нет-нет да и сплющится, но от стали уж не отвертишься ни за что, от стали-то. На перроне — культура: плевательницы, киоск. Восемнадцать минут. И нерешительность обуяла. Заявлюсь — пересудов не оберешься, вообразят, вероятно, невесть чего. Невдомек им, сквалыгам кровным, что не каждый обязательно жлоб. Илье чужого не надо, у него и своего-то нет, но кому ты докажешь. Подавитесь поминками вашими, не поеду. Стою. Тут кондуктор трубит посадку, там проводник грубит, там бабка мятлушкой забилась в стекло: Димка-внук у нее, извольте видеть, до дядьки в Углич отчаливает погостить. Гляди, сиротка, без варежек в жару не гуляй. Сама ты, глиста худощавая, в оба поберегись, пыльцу бы тебе до срока не обтрясли. Что, папаша, к начальнику обращаюсь, отправку будем давать? А тебе почему интересно? — фуражку надвинул на лоб. Отвечаю, что особенно ни к чему, что я про другое желал бы спросить, а отправка сама по себе не тревожит ни с какой стороны, что — отправка, подумаешь, отправляйте. Про что другое? — надменничает. Вы на рысистых испытаниях присутствовали хоть раз? Не то слово — присутствовал, околачивался я на них, большие средства на тотошке просаживал. Помните, значит, как ипподром-то горел, искры так и летели, не так ли? Как не помнить, так и летели, даже заезд собирались сперва отменить. Собирались, только не выгорело это дело у них — понесли коники траверсом. Со старта, помнится, вырвался Поликлет, трехлетка каурый от Политехника с Клептоманией, но на второй кобылка Сметана первой зашла, а Поликлетка на третье переложился, но вот кто ехал тогда на нем — уронила память петлю. Уронила так уронила, путеец сказал, но на этом про лошадей, пожалуйста, завершим, а то отправку, будучи из пожилых, срывать не к лицу вам. Задаетесь вы шибко, папаша, нет бы чем в колокол колотить, пулечку со мной записать по-быстрому. Тут сабля подкатывает: ну, что? Да что ж, пульку отъезжающий записать предлагает. Что же, это не заржавеет у нас, не колесико, лишь карты бы добыть некрапленые. Погодите вы с картами, он же просто отправку хочет сорвать. Помилуйте, дежурный вспылил, прямо шпионство какое-то. Не казните, не повторится, мне, понимаете, колокол ваш думы былые на ум привел, на бегах до пожара висел — ну вылитый. Брякнуло, звякнуло — поехало неудержимо. Крокодиловой кожи заслуженный чемодан в те хитрые годы, пусть сам я не верю теперь, я имел. Почему, впрочем, хитрые — годы как годы, не хитрее других. Чемодан крокодиловой кожи, я повторяю, с замками, в те годы как годы, я, Дзындзырэлла, смею утверждать, имел. Я хватаю его — и дай бог ноги. Хлещет же — не передать. Шли, как известно, и дождь, и поезд, один на Миллерово, вто рой весь день. Милый брат, Емельян признается, как здорово шпарить нам к тебе в гости в Казань, ведь сколько не виделись. Погоди-ка, тревожусь, а почтограмму ты мне направил? Спрашиваешь, прямо с дороги. Да, бегу, стало быть, дебаркадером, догоняю вагон, а вскочить за отсутствием убеждений боязно. Полотеря в те годы как годы во всевозможных местах, я возил в чемодане мастику, тряпки, потертый фетр и швабры поросячьих щетин. Проводник мой с флажками в чехлах зыком благим из тамбура заорал: отцепись, вдруг сорвешься в просак ты, как многие. Не глумись, кастелянша, над пассажирской бедой, чтоб тебе самому сорваться. А Емельяну я сказал, что ау — не застигнет меня его отправление, и что зря, вероятно, спешит он в Казань — я не выбегу. Вам же, Сидор Фомич, пишу приблизительно следующее. Раз приходят некоторые к перевозчику, а тот спит беззаветно. Вот это, я понимаю — загадка, ибо это загадка, а не просто крестьянская быль. Не понимаю только, к которому перевозчику: два у нас перевозчика на Итиле́. Тот — на той стороне зашибает, этот — напротив — на этой. Первый — Ерема по прозвищу Жох, второй наоборот — Фома, и без всякого прозвища. Кличут человека уважительно, по фамилии, и нечего огород городить, правда же? Погибель — лодочника фамилья у нас. И положим, к нему и приходят: работа есть. Он проснулся — а что за труд? Зачем тщеславишься понапрасну, они говорят, будто перевоза помимо еще в некотором ремесле маракуешь. Учить себя никому не позволю, Фома заявил, выкладывайте лучше факт. А попечитель разбушевался, ногами топает, словно я виноват; я и сам-то себя, сироту, в Казани никогда не встречал, если искренно. А куда же я шпарю тогда, инспектор кричит, отвечай. Попечитель, мудрящих я ваших маршрутов не в курсе, но если проездной документ у вас на руках, то не сочтите за дерзость в него заглянуть — там указано. Быть безысходно в просаках — Ильи Джынжирелы удел. Чтоб тебе самому сорваться, проводник мой услышал мои слова. Так сказал ему сгоряча — а сам и сорвался. Что за комиссия, мол, приятель, оборвался, упал кулем под колеса, и оттяпало бо́сую ноженьку, будто серпом. Вижу — ктото знакомый с клинком с поднебесных стропил слетает помочь. Серафим шестикрылый, дежурный, махни ятаганом раза́, отруби-ка всего уж от настоящих мест: зельно болезен, неловкий. И начальник подоспел пожурить. Вам-то что, позавидовал, санаторию себе обеспечили, а людя́м выговорá по вашей линии получай. Не браните, мокропогодица ж, оскользаешься. Мысль: сорвалась, плакала, по-видимому, экспедиция, улыбнулось Илье последнее целование. И опять я в просаке, когда, гордясь, поручику советую в билет заглянуть. Дуралей ты, он оборвал, попечитель билетов по званию брать не обязан, а когда и возьмет другой раз, то литерный и в любой конец, и гляди ты в этот билет, не гляди — все туман, и туда сего предъявитель отправился, сюда ли — ничего не понять, лишь плацкарта бьется купейная на ветру да талон на получение белья шелестит. Нет, не пыльно вы прилепились, земляк, но, видать, не всегда и везде попечителям выгода. Получается, непопечителям иногда очевиднее, куда им путь лег. Взять того же меня, мне — к Орине, ее мне вынь да положь, направление к ней мной держится.

Chapter Notes

06

Despite its many oddities, Between Dog and Wolf features a strict, formal structure: eight prose chapters from the perspective of the itinerant grinder Ilya Zynzyrella; five prose chapters that concern the life and thoughts of the dog-keeper Yakov Palamakhterov; four chapters consisting of 36 poems written by Yakov; and a final chapter made up of a single, separate poem, again authored by Yakov. As Alexander Boguslawski writes, the chapters follow this pattern: ABCABACABACABACBAC (“How Sokolov’s” 205). Elena Kravchenko argues that, in opposition to the visual leanings of the chapters associated with Yakov, Ilya’s chapters “may become less impenetrable if received aurally, which will make its language play come ‘alive’. […] The unmistakable focus in Il’ia’s skaz on oral culture — through numerous allusions to fairy tales and epics — and language, especially its aural qualities illuminated through paronomasia, is juxtaposed with the literariness and visuality of the prose and verse fragments” (The Prose 80).

structure
Accordin to Ilya Petrikeich

One more chapter written “as if” by Ilya in the book. Ilya’s chapters are the 1st, 4th, 6th, 8th, 10th, 12th, 14th, 17th.

structure character
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
Petrikeich

Petrikeich is Ilya’s patronymic (“son of Petrik,” although this first name is not common). D.B. Johnson has noted that the patronymic contains an allusion to the folkloric figure of the “lisa Patrikeevna,” a trickster fox present in Slavic culture (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211). The reference to a fox is not by chance: Ilya will be transfigured into a fox in Orina’s imagination when tied to a railroad (she had brought the hide of her pet fox to a shoemaker who later took advantage of her). Animal motif.

character motif intertextuality folklore intratextuality
06

Despite its many oddities, Between Dog and Wolf features a strict, formal structure: eight prose chapters from the perspective of the itinerant grinder Ilya Zynzyrella; five prose chapters that concern the life and thoughts of the dog-keeper Yakov Palamakhterov; four chapters consisting of 36 poems written by Yakov; and a final chapter made up of a single, separate poem, again authored by Yakov. structure
От Ильи Петрикеича

One more chapter written “as if” by Ilya in the book. Ilya’s chapters are the 1st, 4th, 6th, 8th, 10th, 12th, 14th, 17th.

Text Annotations

station’s waitin room

In the original instead of this usual waiting room, the author mixes up the station and its waiting hall, writing literally “waiting station.”

translation language location
nose

Coming out of chapter 5’s Gogolian parody, it is no surprise that chapter 6 begins with a nose. Read Gogol’s “The Nose” here and an English translation here.

intertextuality intratextuality
the public

Chapter 5, of course, concluded with Yakov’s unpleasant interactions with “the public” as well.

intratextuality
homeless

In the original the author uses the adjective “besprizorny” which appeared in the Soviet era, and according to the National corpus of the Russian language, it was typical in print in particular between 1920s-1940s. Literally meaning “unsupervised,” it was usually used to refer to homeless children, orphans. Boris Zhitkov, author of children’s books (1882-1938), wrote a short story titled “Besprizornaya koshka” (Unsupervised cat), published in his volume Rasskazy o zhivotnykh (Short Stories about Animals), 1935.

language time translation intertextuality Russia
dog

Animal motif.

motif
Our armpits started hurtin from ice-covered roads

Presumably from the difficulty of walking on ice using a crutch.

explanatory
fatigue

Ostanin suggests this is a reference to Vladimir Vysotsky’s 1971 song “Police Protocol”: “Я пил из горлышка, с устатку и не евши” (“You bet: I drank from the bottle, hadn’t eaten, was too tired”) (49). Read the lyrics and an English translation here. Listen to the song here.

intertextuality music
we’re takin medicine

That is, drinking. Alcohol theme.

theme
Alfeyev

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.”

character intertextuality religion bible
Mother Russia is huge, playful, and she barks like a she-wolf in the fog

An allusion to Alexander Radishchev’s Journey from St. Petersburg to Moscow (1790), in particular its epigraph, which was taken from Vasilii Trediakovsky’s “Telemakhida” (1766): “чудище обло, озорно, огромно, стозевно и лаяй” (“a beast who is enormous, disgusting, a-hundred-maws and barking”). Read the original here and an English translation here. Similar wording is used on the following page: “преогромна волчица” (“huge she-wolf”). In chapter 4, Ilya describes his homeland in these terms (cunning, deceptive, rich yet poor at first sight): “It is wonderful outside—our native land. Kinda mother, but strikingly sly, deceitful. In the beginnin, overall, it appears to be—land like land, only poor, with nothin in it. But after you’ve made yourself at home, looked more carefully—there’s everythin in it, except valenki” (R179/E52-53). Animal motif.

intertextuality intratextuality symbol motif
flies

In the original: fleas. This reference to fleas in such a context (Russia, motherland) may well recall one of the most famous stories (skaz) by Nikolay Leskov, Levsha (The Tale of Cross-eyed Lefty from Tula and the Steel Flea), 1881. Read the original here, and the English translation here. Animal motif.

translation motif intertextuality
Yasha

Diminutive form of Yakov.

character register/style
radiant country

As Ostanin notes (49), Avvakum used this adjective related to Rus’ in his autobiography (1672): “выпросил у Бога светлую Русь сатана” (Satan begged God for bright Russia). Read the original here.

intertextuality
we’re all like a bone stuck in its throat

Meaning to annoy someone. However, this episode is literally mentioned in Avvakum’s autobiography (1672), when Agrafena pulls out a fish bone stuck in his throat. Read the original here.

intertextuality
debtors

In chapter 4, Pyotr was worrying about whom to borrow money from (R175-176/E46).

intratextuality
we’re all at fault

The reader will learn, eventually, that Ilya is guilty of murdering several of Yakov and the other hunters’ dogs, so, indeed, he is guilty of everything around these parts.

explanatory intratextuality
my real mother, he said, perhaps died, and I’m lackin a permanent father ’cuz of alcoholism

So Yakov is somehow a besprizornik (see above “homeless”).

character
alcoholism

A crucial theme of the novel, as we have already seen.

theme
Ilya

As we have seen in chapter 4, Ilya seems to be Yakov’s father. Yet, the suggestion is debatable. Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character folklore intertextuality
Yasha

Diminutive form of Yakov.

character register/style
perhaps I am he

Ilya admits the chance of being Yakov’s father.

explanatory character
life is also huge

Enormous just like Russia is. Mark Lipovetsky comments that “Russia is a figurative synonym for Orina, both as the mother who abandons her child (in relation to Yakov) and as an unfaithful lover (in relation to Ilya). Moreover, the author, like Ilya, longs for his beloved, tries to meet her and runs away from her, hates her and pities her” (Russian Postmodernist Fiction 143).

Russia theme explanatory
Ilyich

Ilya uses Yakov’s patronymic as a familiar form of address. However, another reading would be that now that the possibility of Ilya being Yakov’s father has been established, Alfeev (Yakov) is referred to by his patronymic. However, this reading is debatable. D.B. Johnson notes: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211–212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and attacks it. After the hunters steal his crutches, Yakov returns to murder the dogs. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

character intertextuality
get her son on his feet

Irony: Ilya is missing a leg.

irony character
did not give him a vocational education

Ilya, of course, is a knife grinder, while a character whose identity blends between those of Ilya and Yakov works as a furrier.

explanatory
you are a rat for me and not dad

In the original the pun is created with the words “podlets” (scoundrel, miscreant) and “otets” (father).

pun character
Yakov

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character intertextuality
Excuse me, he says, I blew my top, perhaps you ain’t my father. But it’s possible, I am hangin on contrariwise, it’s possible that precisely your father, who knows?

B. Lanin suggests that in Sokolov’s literary world “[k]inship turns out to be as blurred as self-identification, a person cannot recognize himself, where can he recognize his relatives” (130).

explanatory
Therefore, let me be not simply a father but a possible-father, I will be a possible-father to you

Typical ontologic and thematic instability.

theme intertextuality structure character
Alfeyev

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.”

As opposed to the “permanent father” a few lines above.

theme
I need to get to the Tower Junction, to a certain Joy Whatshername

Nineteenth-century song “Otrada” (“Joy”) with lyrics by Sergei Ryskin and music by Mikhail Shishkin. The song describes the singer’s love for a woman who is locked away in a high tower, echoing Orina’s displacement from Ilya. Listen here. Ilya references the same song in chapter 1 (R155-156/E12).

Joy Whatshername

Ostanin notes the “coincidence,” in the original, of the shared initials between Otrada Imiarekovna (Joy Whatshername) and Orina Ignat’evna (49).

From Genesis 2:23, when Adam addresses Eve.

Ilyusha

Diminutive form of Ilya.

character register/style
prodigerant

An inversion of the Prodigal Son story, as the son calls the father prodigal. Read the parable in Luke here. As Boguslawski notes, “the narrator combines here two words - bludnyi (lecherous, sinful, prodigal) and bluzhdaiushchii (wandering) into one - bludushchii. In English a combination of prodigal and itinerant has been used” (“Annotations” 242).

even if she’s no longer among the livin

It can often be difficult to tell whether characters are, in fact, living or dead.

theme
she also worked at the station

In chapter 1, Ilya described how Orina worked at a train station as a dispatcher (R155-156/E12). The implication is thus that Orina is Yakov’s mother and Ilya his father. Railroad theme.

theme character intratextuality
initials in general? Well, I don’t give a darn about them initials

As in chapter 4 (when characters looked for letters “in order to” find yeast), here once again letters turn important.

theme explanatory intratextuality
And he bought me a ticket to the Tower Junction

B. Lanin sees in this train ride to the potential dead Orina/Marina parallels with Nikolai Fyodorov’s belief in humanity’s “common task” to resurrect its ancestors atom by atom and Andrei Platonov’s novel Chevengur (130).

intertextuality
the huge she-wolf is spread far and wide

An allusion to Alexander Radishchev’s Journey from St. Petersburg to Moscow (1790), in particular its epigraph, which was taken from Vasilii Trediakovsky’s “Telemakhida” (1766): “чудище обло, озорно, огромно, стозевно и лаяй” (“a beast who is enormous, disgusting, a-hundred-maws and barking”). Read the original here and an English translation here. Similar wording is used on the following page: “преогромна волчица” (“huge she-wolf”). In chapter 4, Ilya describes his homeland in these terms (cunning, deceptive, rich yet poor at first sight): “It is wonderful outside—our native land. Kinda mother, but strikingly sly, deceitful. In the beginnin, overall, it appears to be—land like land, only poor, with nothin in it. But after you’ve made yourself at home, looked more carefully—there’s everythin in it, except valenki” (R179/E52-53). Animal motif.

intertextuality intratextuality symbol motif
valenok

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

adieu

French: adieu (farewell).

character intertextuality
hardly a spot to put a proof of purity on her

Boguslawski literally translates the Russian set expression meaning “her character (negative) was well known.” Apparently derived from jewelers’ practices when testing the value of a stone. Ilya uses the same phrasing in chapter 1 (R156/E12).

translation phraseologism intratextuality
Those from the Tower Junction

That is, women who work at the train junction tower. Railroad theme.

theme explanatory
switches

Trains play crucial thematic and narrative roles in all of Sokolov’s novels. Here, Orina is moved from one job to another, but more generally, the train switch symbolizes the characters’ many possible paths and multiple identities. Railroad theme.

theme
bare your stump, too—so it is more spectacular

Ilya profits from his invalidity in order to catch the attention and care of passengers.

character explanatory
the car with reserved seats

A train car with reserved seating. Railroad theme.

theme
instrument

Here, Ilya’s crutch and/or the accordion described a few lines below. Elsewhere “instrument” may also refer to his knife-grinding equipment. It is typical in Russia on regional trains to have the most different vendors on board selling goods or playing music in order to earn some money from passengers. Ilya does not head towards the “kupeinyi” wagon by chance: passengers here are expected to be wealthier.

music Russia
Immediately start a melody

We should keep in mind that in chapter 4 Krylobyl noted the “music” produced by knife-grinding: “what kind of sound can be heard at the Wolf River, when one of our grinders starts workin on his grindin stand, ain’t it zhe-zhe-zhe?” (R175/E46).

you know no peace, and don’t have any joy either—you suffered a misfortune

Quote from the Book of Job 3:26.

intertextuality bible religion
the lofty name of the folk invalidual

An ironic twist played on the common Soviet (and today, Russian) honorary title of “Narodnyi artist” (People’s Artist).

language irony pun Russia
invalidual

The word used in the original, “individ,” is literary in Russian, and thus in this context it sounds unnaturally; the actual word Ilya possibly means to use is “invalid.” Boguslawski keeps this linguistic twist.

translation register/style
the most horriblest of us is better than fowls of the air

As Boguslawski notes, this is a paraphrase of Matthew 6:26, a part of the Sermon on the Mount (“Annotations” 242).

A folk tune (the original verb is “raspushchu,” not “protyanu”). Available here.

Boguslawski notes this a “paraphrase of a popular song or chastushka” (“Annotations” 242). Perhaps this one.

intertextuality music
much-beloved Russian

This could be an allusion to Avvakum’s love for the Russian language (“Занеже люблю свой русский природный язык, виршами философскими не обыкл речи красить”; “for I love my native Russian tongue, I am not used to embellish my discourse with philosophical verses”). Read the original here.

intertextuality
flows and splashes

Russian singing is paired with water, or more specifically with a river that covers a long distance (“the journey is long”), just like the Volga, Europe’s longest river.

music theme explanatory
Ilya

In the original, Ilya switches to the biblical form of his name: Elijah. Ilya is frequently compared—by the narrator and by himself—to the prophet Ilya/Elijah, who is commonly associated with lightning and thunder.

translation intertextuality bible religion character
acordeon

A misspelling of accordion. Ilya earlier refers to this instrument in chapter 1 (R150/E15). One of Sokolov’s first publications was “All the Colors of the Rainbow” (“Vse tsveta radugi”), a short story about a blind accordionist.

intratextuality music self-reference
have you sold some manure

Boguslawski notes: “When a poor person buys an expensive thing, he may be asked, jokingly, ‘Have you sold some manure?’ The question indicates that the only expected possession of such a poor person is manure” (“Annotations” 242).

translation phraseologism
Your Lameness

Ilya is playing on the address “Your Majesty.”

phraseologism pun
orderly

That is, the one at the hospital.

explanatory
Uncle Vanya

Ivan/Vanya/Vanechka. An allusion to Anton Chekhov’s Uncle Vanya. Read the original Russian here and English translation here. Since the morgue is described as a theater, it is not surprising that the nurse is an “uncle Vanya.” This is the name of the male nurse at the hospital where Ilya is treated (R183/E59). However, another Ivan, a “glass man” who chokes to death, appears in the Note XXXI (R268–269/E209). The name Ivan (John) has Hebrew origins and means “God is gracious.” In the Christian tradition, it is linked with the figures of John the Apostle and John the Baptist.

intertextuality intratextuality character religion bible
theater

That is, the morgue, as we have seen in chapter 4. Alesia Atroshchenko examines how Sokolov depicts “death as a performance” and morgue as a site between “two worlds (life and death)” in this episode of the novel (“Ornamentalizm” 300).

location setting intratextuality
artist

In chapter 4 “artists” were called the dead bodies in the morgue.

intratextuality
in a tilted cap and with a gold tooth

Quotation from a well-known Soviet blatnaya pesnya in which the male hero, “in a tilted cap and with a gold tooth,” ends indeed dead in the end. Read some versions of the original here. Listen to it here. Sokolov suggests to listen to the entire song available at this link, as the singers “sing in the proper style and dress in the ‘bandit’ fashion of the time.” Sokolov also explains: “When Ilya sees the body of the murdered accordionist in the morgue, he remembers this song. The guy’s face was cut up with a dangerous razor, a popular criminal device in those days. The cap, gold tooth and boots of the murdered man suggest to Ilya that the guy belonged to this milieu and was killed by their own, the blatnye. By the way, do you remember the ‘gold-toothed couplers’ [from chapter 2]?” (personal communication, August 21, 2023).

intratextuality music
kirza

An artificial leather most commonly used for boots in the USSR and Russia. A cheap leather substitute invented by Mikhail Pomortsev (1851–1916) and presented in Liège at the Exposition Universelle et Internationale in 1905, although there is an erroneous version claiming that the name “kirza” appeared during the Great Patriotic War as an abbreviation for “Kirov Artificial Leather Factory” (Kirovsky zavod iskusstvennykh kozh), where mass production of leather substitute based on multilayer fabric with synthetic rubber impregnation was deployed. Kirza is mainly used in the manufacture of military equipment, such as boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
acordeon

intratextuality music self-reference
three-row instrument

A three-row button accordion.

music
bandura

A Ukrainian stringed folk instrument similar to the zither and lute. Sometimes it is called a kobza, which is, however, a slightly different instrument (especially in terms of shape and number of strings). Its strings may be from a minimum of 12 up to 70. As Boguslawski notes, the word can be used to “denote any kind of a musical instrument” (“Annotations” 242). Here, it represents the accordion that Ilya is discussing. The figure of the “kobzar” (more generally intended as “bard”) was immortalized in Ukrainian culture by the most famous collection of poems by Taras Shevchenko, titled Kobzar (1840).

foreign music
ours

That is, some Russian/Soviet song.

music Russia explanatory
chastushkas

Traditional humorous Russian or Ukrainian folk songs consisting of four-line rhymed stanzas. Listen to an example here.

Russia intertextuality music folklore
Crematorium they were tryin, homeless vagrant they were fryin (the management’s so shrewd), they look in—and he is teasin: Close the door, my butt is freezin

One of Ilya’s chastushki. This text is sung by Ostap Bender in the 1968 Soviet movie The Golden Calf. Watch the episode here.

music intertextuality
dance

Dancing. This word is crucial to Sokolov’s art. Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek “χορεία” and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham’s chorea (also known as “St. Vitus’s dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video here. Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

intratextuality music self-reference intertextuality
Yakov

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Ilyich

Ilya uses Yakov’s patronymic as a familiar form of address. However, another reading would be that now that the possibility of Ilya being Yakov’s father has been established, Alfeev (Yakov) is referred to by his patronymic. However, this reading is debatable. D.B. Johnson notes: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211–212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and attacks it. After the hunters steal his crutches, Yakov returns to murder the dogs. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

character intertextuality
one

That is, one leg.

explanatory
Uncle Vanya

Ivan/Vanya/Vanechka. An allusion to Anton Chekhov’s Uncle Vanya. Read the original Russian here and English translation here. Since the morgue is described as a theater, it is not surprising that the nurse is an “uncle Vanya.” This is the name of the male nurse at the hospital where Ilya is treated (R183/E59). However, another Ivan, a “glass man” who chokes to death, appears in the Note XXXI (R268–269/E209). The name Ivan (John) has Hebrew origins and means “God is gracious.” In the Christian tradition, it is linked with the figures of John the Apostle and John the Baptist.

hurdy-gurdy

Used here as a synonym for accordion.

Boguslawski translates literally the Russian variation of the set expression “s barskogo plecha”: given to another out of pity, but sensing one’s superiority.

intratextuality
At a train station there sat a soldier, a rake and dandy, brother-in-arms, just a lieutenant by rankin order, but a field marshal of female charms.

Quote (with little variations) from a blatnaya pesnya. Listen to a version of it here. Read it here. “Blatnaya pesnya” refers to a musical genre closely associated with Soviet criminal subculture, especially carceral systems. These songs use the language of criminals and associated imagery.

music intertextuality Russia
bayan

A chromatic button accordion from Russia. It was developed in the early 20th century and named after Boyan, a bard from The Lay of Igor’s Campaign, an epic Old Russian poem.

music intertextuality
A certain madam entered the station, and she was serious, graceful, and neat; lieutenant quickly stood at attention and dropped his breeches straight at her feet

A quotation from the same blatnaya pesnia (again with little variations) goes on. Read it here. “Blatnaya pesnya” refers to a musical genre closely associated with Soviet criminal subculture, especially carceral systems. These songs use the language of criminals and associated imagery.

music intertextuality
certain madam

An echo of Та Дама (That Dame), i.e., Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

location Russia
I will pour you for that again. And both of us took a swig

Alcohol theme.

theme
sharp speed skate

In the original the skate is specifically Norwegian. Mentioned in chapter 14 (R259/E194). According to Sokolov, “Norway was once considered the best in the production of iceskates. In Russia, cross-country skates from Norway were valued, and they were called Norways: long, high-speed. Another common name for cross-country skates is knives. Ilya compares the train with a Norwegian knife, that is, with a long skate. Skates with a wide skid and steeply curved socks are called snowshoes: because they can be ridden not only on ice, but also on packed snow, on roads, and pedestrian paths” (personal communication, August 21, 2023). An echo of the character Pavel Petrovich Norvegov from Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools.

translation explanatory self-reference intratextuality
manul

A manul, also known as the Pallas’s cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character’s name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means “God with us” (16). The character Manul appears in chapters 1 and 4. Animal motif.

intratextuality explanatory motif
snuggled like a needle in a haystack

A play on the expression “to look for a needle in a haystack” (equal in Russian and English). Yet in the original, instead of “haystack,” an Old Church Slavonic word meaning edge or fringe is used. Thus, this phrase could also be “like a sewing needle in a fringe.” One more allusion to the theme of sewing.

theme phraseologism translation
the train seems to have a completely unearthly destination

Boguslawski renders in this way the twist contained in the original from the standard “poezd osobogo naznacheniya” (special train) to “poezd nezdeshnogo naznacheniya” (alien-destination train). A 1979 Soviet movie is called “Poezd chrezvychainogo naznacheniya” (Extraordinary Train): Railroad theme.

Millerovo

foreign Russia location theme
assorti

French: assorted.

foreign
Yemelyan

The name Emeli’an (Emil) is derived from the Latin aemulus which means rival, literally “emulator.” In this context, it’s a fitting name given the relationship between Ilya and his brother, as well as the fluid nature of the divisions between characters’ identities. Aemilianus was also briefly Roman emperor in 253. Ostanin notes that Emel’yan was also the name of Pugachev, a Cossack ataman who led a popular insurrection during the reign of Catherine the Great (52). His figure turned literary thanks to Pushkin and his historical novel The Captain’s Daughter (1836). In Pushkin’s novel, Pugachev is described through the eyes of the nobleman Grinev who dislikes this illiterate “drunkard” wandering outlaw, yet does not refuse him his hareskin coat as a token of his gratitude. During the first Russo-Turkish war (1768–1774) Pugachev served in the Russian army as khorunzhy, a military rank mentioned in chapter 3.

character foreign intertextuality
Zhizhirella

Another variation on Ilya’s unusual last name, which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book. It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker’s essay, “Gamesman’s Sketches (Found in a Bottle),” CASS 21.3-4: 356). However, as Korovashko suggests, “Ilya Petrikevich becomes a kind of Cinderella ‘squared’: if the latter lost only his shoe, he lost both his leg and the crutches that compensate for its absence” (277).

character intertextuality
we drained one

That is, to drain their cups. Alcohol theme.

theme
for Bruderschaft

German: brotherhood. A drinking convention whereby two people link arms at the elbow and drain their glasses to express friendship or “brotherhood.” Here, the act is literalized as Ilya and Emel’ian recognize themselves as true brothers. Alcohol theme.

Animal motif. For an analysis of Sokolov’s use of butterfly imagery, see Ashcheulova’s “Motiv babochki.”

motif
Dimka

Diminutive of Dmitry.

register/style
Uglich

A town located on the Volga in the Yaroslavl oblast. It is famous for the assassination of Ivan the Terrible’s son, Dmitry (here recalled also through the grandson’s name), who was sent to Uglich in 1584 after his father died. The 10-year-old boy was found dead on May 15, 1591, his throat cut in the palace courtyard. Although suspicion fell on the tsar’s chief advisor, Boris Godunov, official investigators concluded that Dmitry’s death was an accident. The story is mentioned also in Pushkin’s play Boris Godunov (1831).

location intertextuality Russia
hippodrome was burnin

According to Ostanin (52), they are talking about the historical Moscow hippodrome, which was definitively destroyed by a fire in 1949 (and then rebuilt). From the Greek ἱππόδρομος (ἵππος, “horse” and δρόμος, “course”) — a stadium for horse and chariot racing. Now used to refer to a horse track. Here, as in chapter 5, the narrators refer to the Central Moscow Hippodrome, which was founded in 1834 (see also R185/63).

intratextuality Russia location foreign
Polykleitus

Polykleitos was a famous sculptor in Ancient Greece (5th century BC). He is particularly known for his lost treatise (a canon of body proportions), the “Canon of Polykleitos”, setting out his mathematical basis of an idealised male body shape.

explanatory foreign intertextuality
black

The original is “каурый” (chestnut).

translation
Kleptomania

An impulse control disorder that urges to steal. Sokolov affirms that “the names of the horses are invented” (personal communication, June 27 2023).

explanatory
Sour Cream

Smetana, sour cream typical for Central and Eastern Europe. According to Ostanin (53), here Sokolov refers to the story of the horse Smetanka, an Arabian stallion that in 1776 was bought from the sultan Abdul Hamid I by count Alexey Orlov for 60,000 rubles, in a time when stallions in Russia sold for approximately 5,000 rubles. Smetanka had 19 ribs on each side, instead of 18. The horse Smetanka is mentioned also in Lev Tolstoy’s Kholstomer.

He is proposing to play cards.

explanatory
unmarked cards

Altered in order to be distinguished (and then used to cheat, or perform tricks). Here the speaker wants cards to be unaltered, unmarked, regular.

explanatory
Your bell brought past thoughts

A twisted yet evident reference to the Russian writer and thinker Aleksandr Herzen (1812-1870). “Kolokol” (Bell) was the first Russian censorship-free weekly newspaper in Russian (and French) languages; it was launched by Herzen and Nikolai Ogaryov in London (1857–1865) and later Geneva (1865–1867). Byloe i dumy (My Past and Thoughts) is Herzen’s famous extensive autobiography, a classic of Russian literature.

intratextuality
We have two ferrymen on the Itil

As everything is doubled, we have also here two Charons.

explanatory symbol structure theme
The first, Yeryoma nicknamed Cad; the second, in contrast, Foma, and without any nickname

A reference to the set expression “Я ему про Фому, а он мне про Ерёму” (I talk about Foma, but he tells me about Eryoma), used when people do not understand each other.

phraseologism translation
Yeryoma

Eryoma is one of the two oarsmen who carry people (dead or alive) across the river (a variation of the Charon Greek myth). The other oarsman is Foma Pogibel’. Eryoma is a diminutive of the name Eremei, Jeremiah. Jeremiah is one of the most important prophets in the Hebrew Bible (also known as the “weeping prophet”), author of the Book of Jeremiah, the Book of Kings, and the Book of Lamentations.

character intertextuality religion bible
Foma

Foma Doom (Pogibel’ in the original) is one of the two oarsmen who carry people (dead or alive) across the river (a variation of the Charon Greek myth). The other oarsman is Eryoma (diminutive of Eremei, Jeremiah). However, in Note XXXI the oarsman is called Pavel, just like the character who sends his uncle Pyotr to get yeast in Gorodnishche. As underlined by one of the epigraphs in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, the biblical name of Pavel is somehow interchangeable: “Saul, who is called Paul” (see Acts 13:9–10). As for Foma, he carries a biblical name, too (Thomas), whose Aramaic origin suggests the idea of the “twin.” This apostle is famous as “Doubting Thomas” due to his denial of the resurrection of Jesus, according to the Gospel of John (see John 20:24–31). In the Orthodox tradition, the Sunday following Easter is called “Thomas Sunday”: the day when Christ appeared to his disciples; it took seeing Jesus’ body for Thomas to name him “My Lord and my God.”
